item.title: UFO (Pink Lady song)
item.description:
“UFO” (Pink Lady song) ðŸ”—

This article is about the 1977 single “UFO” by the Japanese duo Pink Lady.

Background ðŸ”—

This section details the creative team behind the song, noting that Shunichi Tokura composed the music and YÅ« Aku wrote the lyrics, as with Pink Lady’s previous singles. The song’s theme is about a woman falling in love with a man she considers “out of this world.” It also mentions the evolution of the song’s performance, highlighting the addition of “UFO” chants in live versions compared to the original studio recording. The section also describes the iconic silver sequin outfits and elaborate dance choreography associated with live performances, including the “UFO greeting” and exaggerated alien movements. Mie and Kei (Keiko Masuda) are mentioned as the performers.

Release and reception ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the commercial success and critical acclaim of “UFO.” It states that the single sold 1,950,000 copies, making it Pink Lady’s best-selling single. It also highlights the song’s chart performance, including its ten-week reign at the top of the Japanese singles chart and its recognition as the best-selling single of 1978 by Oricon. The song’s achievement as the duo’s third consecutive million-selling single and fifth of nine consecutive number-one singles is also mentioned. The song’s number one position on the Japanese Music Labo chart is also noted. The section also mentions the song’s accolades, including winning the grand prize at the 20th Japan Record Awards and being voted the best song of 1978 by The Best Ten. The song’s continued relevance is demonstrated by its high rankings in JASRAC’s Top 10 Works Distributed in Japan in 2015, 2018, and 2019, due to its use in UQ Mobile commercials.

Other uses ðŸ”—

This section outlines the various ways “UFO” has been used in popular culture. It mentions Pink Lady’s performance of a version with altered lyrics for Nissin Yakisoba U.F.O. commercials in 1978. The song’s inclusion in the video game Just Dance Wii and its performance on Pink Lady and Jeff are also noted. The section also mentions Pink Lady’s re-recording of the song for their 2010 album INNOVATION and FEMM’s cover version released in 2016.

Track listing (7" vinyl) ðŸ”—

This section provides the track listing for the original 7" vinyl release of “UFO,” including the A-side (“UFO”) and the B-side (“Lady X”). It credits YÅ« Aku for the lyrics and Shunichi Tokura for the music composition and arrangement. The lengths of both songs are also provided.

Charts ðŸ”—

This section lists the peak positions of “UFO” on Japanese music charts in 1977, including reaching number 1 on the Oricon Singles Chart and the Japanese Music Labo Chart.

Pink Babies version ðŸ”—

This section details the cover version of “UFO” by the tribute group Pink Babies, released as a single on February 15, 2017. It mentions that “Monday Mona Lisa Club” was the B-side. It also notes that three versions of the single were released, each including a cover of a Linda Yamamoto song. The section also mentions Pink Babies’ disbandment two months after the single’s release, with their final show held on May 26.

Track listings ðŸ”—

This section provides the track listings for the three different versions (Type-A, Type-B, and Type-C) of the Pink Babies’ “UFO” single. Each version includes “UFO” and “Monday Mona Lisa Club,” along with different Linda Yamamoto covers and other songs. Songwriters YÅ« Aku, Shunichi Tokura, and Shizuka IjÅ«in are credited.

Charts ðŸ”—

This section lists the peak position of the Pink Babies’ “UFO” single on the Japanese Oricon Singles Chart in 2017, reaching number 31.

Other cover versions ðŸ”—

This section lists various artists who have covered “UFO” over the years. Some of the artists mentioned include Chisato Moritaka, Yuko Hara, McKee, MAX, Trasparenza, Chinephile, Keiko Masuda, Morning Musume, Anna Tsuchiya, Mari Natsuki, Chiaki Takahashi, Asami Imai, Melon Kinenbi, Sumire Matsubara, Yu Takahashi, Yuki Murakami, FEMM, Amiaya, AKB48 members Yuki Kashiwagi and Mayu Watanabe, Boys and Men, and Honoka Minori.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_(Pink_Lady_song)
